The original draft of the agreement has been revised, and in its
present state is quite different
from its original form. The greatest change is the elimination of
the dating system which was objected to by several -fraternities.

were made for the purpose of simplifying and clarifying the text

At the last meeting of the Middle States Collegiate Athletic
Conference, held in Philadelphia
last week, the date of the M. S.
C. A. track meet was moved forward. Professor J. Trueman
Thompson, representing Johns
Hopkins University, urged this
change, and, after much discussion, it was accepted by the EXecutive Committee.

In April of last year a group of
students interested in literary, especially journalistic, enterprises
formed a local society to promote
college journalism on the campus. In the following June this
organization sent a petition to Pi
Delta Epsilon, a national honorary journalistic fraternity, asking that a chapter might be established at Hopkins. The application was given careful consideration by the members of Pi Delta
Epsilon, all of whom seemed favorably impressed with the idea
of establishing a chapter at this
Consequently, at
University.
their next convention, held this
winter, it was decided to grant a
charter to Johns Hopkins.

Take It From The Air
music, but news, speeches, mesNOTsagesonlyof every
sort, are today being picked
out of the air.
"How has this come about?" we ask.
The new impetus given to radio development
may be definitely associated with the development of the high power vacuum tube, for that
made broadcasting possible. And the power
tube originated from a piece of purely theoretical research, which had no connection with radio.
When a scientist in the Research Laboratories
of the General Electric Company found that
electric current could be made to pass through
the highest possible vacuum and could be varied
according to fixed laws, he established the principle of the power tube and laid the foundation
for the "tron" group of devices.
These devices magnify the tiny telephone
currents produced by the voice and supply
them to the antenna, which broadcasts the
messages. At the receiving end, smaller
"trons", in turn, magnify the otherwise imperceptible messages coming to them from the
receiving antenna.
Great accomplishments are not picked out
of the air. Generally, as in this case, they grow
from one man's insatiable desire to find out
the "how" of things.
Scientific research discovers the facts. Practical applications follow in good time.

Take It From The Air
music, but news, speeches, mesNOTsagesonlyof every
sort, are today being picked
out of the air.
"How has this come about?" we ask.
The new impetus given to radio development
may be definitely associated with the development of the high power vacuum tube, for that
made broadcasting possible. And the power
tube originated from a piece of purely theoretical research, which had no connection with radio.
When a scientist in the Research Laboratories
of the General Electric Company found that
electric current could be made to pass through
the highest possible vacuum and could be varied
according to fixed laws, he established the principle of the power tube and laid the foundation
for the "tron" group of devices.
These devices magnify the tiny telephone
currents produced by the voice and supply
them to the antenna, which broadcasts the
messages. At the receiving end, smaller
"trons", in turn, magnify the otherwise imperceptible messages coming to them from the
receiving antenna.
Great accomplishments are not picked out
of the air. Generally, as in this case, they grow
from one man's insatiable desire to find out
the "how" of things.
Scientific research discovers the facts. Practical applications follow in good time.
